North by Northwest is considered by many to be one of the best films of all time. It is highly rated by many critics and film review sites. And understandably so, to a certain extent. It's a light adventure/comedy that's good at what it does, and to top it off, it was directed by Alfred Hitchcock, one of the greatest filmmakers of all time.

Now, I'm not going to sit here and delve into all the cinematic techniques and themes in the film that are signatures to Hitchcock's glory. I'm going to, in a modern standpoint, conclude on the entertainment value of the movie. And there is no doubt in my mind that North by Northwest is entertainment gold - to the people of the 50?s and 60?s. But now, the film is undeniably outdated and a bit corny. It's like watching a structurally well made James Bond film from the 60?s. The orchestral music during the romantic scenes and the cheesy one liners make it a bit difficult to be fully entertained, especially to those who are so used to the stunning visuals and CGI of the 21st century.

The film's protagonist, Roger Thornhill (Cary Grant), gets mixed up with the CIA trying to capture a foreign spy, Phillip Vandamm (James Mason). Throughout the film, Roger is in conflict with the love interest, Eve Kendall (Eva Marie Saint). Trust is a big theme that gets tossed around at every twist and turn in the story. The film is filled with sexual symbols, play on words, and subtle hints that are characteristic of a Hitchcock film. Therefore, the film is a great educational piece that can be analyzed and studied. I feel North by Northwest is more of a film you'd see in a classroom setting than a film you'd like to see during movie night with friends.

Hitchcock fanatics will probably be pissed at the 3.5 rating, but let's face it, we live in a time where even The Matrix is considered visually outdated.

While not quite Hitchcock's best, NORTH BY NORTHWEST is nevertheless one of his most thrilling, and funny, motion pictures. It stars Cary Grant as an ad executive who gets mistaken for a government agent and has to go on the run in order to survive. Sound familiar? That's because the plot is kind of similar to Hitchcock's own SABOTEUR and THE MAN WHO KNEW TOO MUCH (although you can be certain that Cary Grant's character didn't; the bad guys just think he does). This simple premise provided for a myriad of exciting set-pieces that exemplify the kind of suspense-building and thrills that Hitch's audience were most certainly used to by this point in his career. Cary Grant is quite a good replacement for the everyman character that James Stewart played so well, and Eva Marie Saint plays a nice twist on the femme fatale as this film's Hitchcock blonde. Still, what struck me so much was how funny this film was. At certain points, it was like watching a comedy of errors combined with a spy thriller. There was also a lot more obvious sexual innuendo than in any Hitchcock picture I've seen before. Signs of the changing times, maybe? Moving on, even though it wasn't as tightly written as some of Hitchcock's other films, being essentially a bunch of action set-pieces strung together, it was still rather inventive and the momentum was kept going at a pretty good pace throughout. In particular, the crop-dusting scene and the climactic sequence on Mount Rushmore stand out from the rest, as I'm sure they do to many others who've seen the film. However, what made this not quite as perfect as could have been has a lot do with Hitchcock's tendency to do a lot of shooting on sound stages. As a result, a car chase that takes place early on (with a drunk Cary Grant) was less thrilling and believable than it could have been, and Bernard Herrmann's score had to compensate (a little too much, perhaps). And, the villains this time around weren't as memorable, mostly because we don't really see them do anything villainous. Still, James Mason was a pleasure to watch, and we get to see Martin Landau play a heavy. Overall, I do think this is better than the previous Hitchcock films I mentioned, if for no other reason than that there's more of what worked in those films. Still, at 136 minutes, it is a little too long and, like many other of Hitchcock's movies I've seen, the ending was too abrupt and a little bit of a cheat. So, while its reach does somewhat exceed its grasp in terms of the action, NORTH BY NORTHWEST is still a suitably thrilling action/adventure that ranks among the most entertaining that Hitchcock ever made.

This was a Hitchcock classic that I didn't see for the longest time. The movie has a great reputation for a reason. After finally seeing it, I have to say that I loved it. There wasn't a moment in this movie when I was bored. Hitchcock had the tendency to be dark at times, but not with this movie. This movie is full-on fun, and I don't know if Hitchcock has ever purely entertained me more. 

Advertising executive Roger O. Thornhill lives a rather normal and peaceful life. When at lunch with some friends, Roger is mistaken for George Kaplan. He is abducted and taken to Philip Vandamm. Roger is clearly confused and cannot answer any of Vandamm's questions.  He winds up being released, but now he wants to figure out this mystery. When Thornhill is horribly framed for a murder, he must go on the run and figure out this mystery at the same time.

This is "fun" Alfred Hitchcock at his peak. Everything just clicked with this movie: iconic set-pieces, an engrossing story, lots of humor, a great musical score, and first-rate performances. Headlining the movie is Cary Grant as Roger Thornhill. Honestly, Grant has played similar characters dozens of times. And yet each time I see him play this kind of character, I'm struck with what a great actor he was. His Thornhill is spot-on.

Eva Marie Saint plays the mysterious love interest, Eve. Supposedly, Grace Kelly was the first choice for the part, but by 1959 she was a Princess consort of Monaco. No Grace Kelly, so out of dozens of other candidates, Hitchcock picked Saint. She works just fine in her role, providing a good foil to Grant's witticisms.

The supporting cast all turn in solid performances. James Mason is appropriately villain-like as Vandamm. Jesse Royce Landis is pretty comical as Thornhill's mother. But my favorite supporting performance is Martin Landau as Leonard. Maybe it's because I've seen him many times on Mission Impossible, but I think he plays an excellent villain.

The story isn't really original. Hitchcock made at least three movies like this. But what really sets this movie apart from Hitchcock's classic "falsely accused man on the run" movies, other than its sharp sense of humor, is its iconic action scenes. Probably the most notable is the crop-duster chase. If only action scenes could be this original today. And the finale, Mount Rushmore chase is another incredible action scene with spectacle, originality, and tension.

Overall, North by Northwest vaulted itself into my favorite Hitchcock movies. Full of suspense, humor, intrigue, and original action; this movie hits the mark.

Alfred Hitchcock's North by Northwest is a well crafted suspense thriller that has an engaging plot, a great cast and immaculate directing from the master of suspense. The actors that star opposite Grant are wonderful as well; an Eva Marie and James Mason are fine choices and bring a memorable presence to the screen. Hitchcock directs great film and this is among his greater efforts as a director. What makes him so unique as a director is his style in terms of delivering thrills and suspense. Hitchcock is in a class by himself. North by Northwest is an accomplished picture that is confident, thrilling and above all, memorable. The film contains one of the most recognizable scenes in any Hitchcock film, the scene where Cary Grant gets chased by the crop dusting plane ranks as one of the best scenes along with the shower scene in Psycho. This is a great film that will surely please Hitchcock fans. At times the film does have a few weak areas, however the strong performances and effective directing keep things together well enough to make this a worthwhile film to watch. This is a blend great suspense and thriller elements that truly make this one of the standout pictures of the genre. As it stands, North by Northwest is a near flawless film that is aided by a strong cast, an engaging story and effective directing that will keep you on the edge of your seat. If you love a well executed suspense film, North by Northwest will surely appeal to you, and is a must see.

As much as simply enthrallingHitchcock's risky and briskly adventure is the apt catalyst to this complex espionage thrillerNorth By NorthwestHitchcock's risky and briskly adventure is the apt catalyst to this complex espionage thriller. As much as simply enthralling its first half is, that follows a linear singular path collecting its plot points like a reward the film moves with ferocious pace and nail biting close calls. But the second half is the one with the real meat. Its complex and at times overstuffed characters with their own agendas and schemes does work since the man behind the camera is Hitchcock. He never lets the content go damp which often happens in such husky script. There is a sense of similarity in here to Polanski's Chinatown, starring Nicholson. And similar to it, the uncertainty is the key to its success.The makers are consistently revealing cards in order to keep the audience tangled in the whirls of these flips and turns that can be difficult to swallow. It is a mature script that always chooses over leaving the room with a cutthroat message rather than an explosion. The euphoric energy of the ping pong that the writers play of who is with whom theories, with Hitchcock's sharp execution it never wears off. Also, there is real ruggedness in here, the characters have the range to look elegant and also pull out the most sinister deed of all.Grant as the real victim proving his innocence isn't always in his A game, his performance isn't persistent in its tone. But what saves the day is both Saint's performance and her character, her alluring suave nature and guns blazing unflinchingly puts her on top of the list. Armed with a smart and meticulous adaptation, Hitchcock takes his time, he is milking out the best from each moment. North By Northwest is less Hitchcock-ish than usual, and it is certainly refreshing.

The script revolves around a confusion of identities, where an ordinary citizen is mistaken for a spy and ends up in a tremendous confusion with gigantic repercussions on his personal life and national security.The script is quite good and the story has no dead moments. It entertains the audience in a perfect way until the end and makes us curious to know what is really going on, curiosity being an important part of what keeps us stuck in the film (and one of the reasons I prefer to hardly talk about the plot). The main character, played by Cary Grant, was so well thought out that we quickly established an affective and sympathetic link with her, caring about what will happen to her. It goes without saying that, although the cast is very good, it is really Cary Grant who stands out here. Eva Marie Saint is good, but she never leaves the shadow of the male protagonist. Another actor that deserves a positive note is Martin Landau.Technically, it is an impeccable film, to the taste of director Hitchcock. It is full of symbolic scenes or with more than one meaning, some of them bordering on the dreamlike. Some of the scenes are truly striking, like those that were shot on Mount Rushmore. The camera and film work is excellent and cinematography perfectly harmonizes color, light, shadow and contrast, resulting in a visually elegant film, although with the characteristics of a film of its time, of course. The soundtrack is also quite good, as are the sets and costumes.
